title-group.article-title: Review of Survey Articles Regarding Medication Therapy Management (MTM) Services/Programs in the United States

contrib-group.aff: 1Division of Pharmacy Administration, College of Pharmacy, The University of Texas at Austin, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: Karen L. Rascati, Division of Health Outcomes and Pharmacy Practice, College of Pharmacy, The University of Texas at Austin, Campus Mail Code A1930, Austin TX 78712, USA Email: krascati@mail.utexas.edu

abstract.p: Objective: To provide a summary of published survey articles regarding the provision of medication therapy management (MTM) services in the United States. Methods: A literature search was conducted to identify original articles on MTM-related surveys conducted in the United States, involving community and outpatient pharmacists, physicians, patients, or pharmacy students and published by the primary researchers who conducted the study. Search engines used included PubMed, Medline, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts (IPA). If MTM was in the keyword list, mesh heading, title, or abstract, the article was reviewed. References from these articles were searched to determine whether other relevant articles were available. Results: A total of 405 articles were initially reviewed; however, only 32 articles met the study requirements. Of the 32 articles, 17 surveyed community/outpatient pharmacists, 3 surveyed pharmacy students, 4 surveyed physicians, and 8 surveyed patients. The survey periods varied across the different studies, with the earliest survey conducted in 2004 and the most recent survey conducted in 2009. The surveys were conducted via the telephone, US mail, interoffice mail, e-mails, Internet/Web sites, hand-delivered questionnaires, and focus groups. Conclusion: Despite the identified barriers to the provision of MTM services, pharmacists reportedly found it professionally rewarding to provide these services. Pharmacists claimed to have adequate clinical knowledge, experience, and access to information required to provide MTM services. Pharmacy students were of the opinion that the provision of MTM services was important to the advancement of the pharmacy profession and in providing patients with a higher level of care. Physicians supported having pharmacists adjust patients’ drug therapy and educate patients on general drug information but not in selecting patients’ drug therapy. Finally, patients suggested that alternative ways need to be explored in describing and marketing MTM services for it to be appealing to them.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The 2006 implementation of the Medicare Part D prescription drug benefit (in accordance with the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act [MMA] of 2003) required the provision of medication therapy management (MTM) services to high-risk patients through the Medicare Advantage Prescription Drug (MA-PD) plan, stand-alone prescription drug plan (PDP), and special needs plan (SNP). These high-risk patients are Medicare Part D beneficiaries with multiple chronic illnesses, who are on multiple covered Part D medications and whose medication costs could likely exceed a predetermined threshold level. The cost threshold was reduced from $4000 per year in 2006 to $3000 in 2010. 1,2 According to a 2010 report by the Kaiser Family Foundation (KFF), about 59% of Medicare beneficiaries are enrolled in the Medicare Part D program 3 and about 25% of this eligible Medicare Part D population were estimated to meet the criteria required to receive MTM services. 2 In addition, the MTM services were also provided to non-Part D patients and were also included in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) which was signed into law in 2010.

Both Pellegrino 4 and McGivney 5 compared and contrasted definitions associated with pharmacy services to the definition of MTM. For example, “disease state management” may involve pharmacy services but does not focus on medications nor include multiple disease conditions. MTM differs from patient counseling because it is delivered independent of dispensing and involves collaboration with patients and providers.

According to a consensus definition supported by 11 national professional pharmacy organizations, MTM is “a distinct service or group of services that optimizes therapeutic outcomes for individual patients.” 6 MTM services are targeted at improving patient’s drug use, clinical outcomes, and quality of life, while reducing the risk for adverse events and the overall health care costs. MTM services include conducting an assessment of the patient’s health status, developing an appropriate drug treatment plan, monitoring and evaluating the patient’s response to therapy, reviewing the patient’s medication profile to detect and prevent drug related problems, providing adequate patient education, promoting patient’s medication adherence, promoting disease prevention and wellness programs, and collaborating with other health care providers to improve care and health outcomes for the individual patient. 6 In 2005, the American Pharmacists Association (APhA) and the National Association of Chain Drug Stores Foundation identified 5 core elements required of any MTM program. These include medication therapy review, a personal medication record, a medication action plan, intervention and referral, and documentation and follow-up. 7

While the need to provide MTM services cannot be overemphasized, the lack of standardization in the design and delivery of these services has the potential to affect the quality and possibly reduce the intended effect of implementing the provision of these services. 8 Many insurance plans have been reported to provide MTM services via mailings and in-house call centers rather than employing the services of community pharmacists to provide direct (face-to-face) care. 9,10 Pharmacist providers are also faced with a number of challenges which include reimbursement issues (ie, low and/or delayed payments), variability of program content due to different health plans, administrative burdens from third-party payers, and poor interprofessional collaboration due to unfavorable physician perception regarding the ability of pharmacists to provide these services. 9 –11

Pharmacists, 12
–28 pharmacy students, 29 –31 physicians, 32
–35 and patients 36
–43 have been surveyed on issues centered around implementation, enrollment, delivery, compensation, attitudes, perception, satisfaction, willingness to pay, training needs, skills, and knowledge as these relate to the provision of MTM services. While each study reveals findings that may have the potential to provide insight on how to restructure the design and delivery of MTM services, there is not one document that summarizes these findings into a single report in order to provide comprehensive information for future research purposes. In addition, this may be useful to inform future MTM delivery and implementation. The objective of this study is to provide a summary of published survey articles regarding the provision of MTM services in the United States.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Search engines used included PubMed, Medline, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts (IPA). The search terms used were combinations of the following key phrases: Medication Therapy Management, MTM, pharmacy services, survey, questionnaire, Medicaid Modernization Act. Also, if MTM was in the keyword list, mesh heading, title, or abstract, the article was reviewed. References from these articles were searched to determine whether other relevant articles were available. The search included articles through October 2011. Articles were included for this summary if they reported on MTM-related surveys conducted in the United States, involving community pharmacists, physicians, patients, or pharmacy students and were published by the researchers who conducted the surveys (ie, not a report of a study conducted by other authors).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
A total of 405 articles were initially reviewed, however, only 32 of these articles met the study’s requirements (Figure 1). Other articles that measured costs and clinical and humanistic outcomes of MTM services are summarized in a companion article. Of the 32 articles, 17 surveyed pharmacists, 12
–28 3 surveyed pharmacy students, 29 –31 4 surveyed physicians, 32
–35 and 8 surveyed patients. 36
–43 The survey periods vary across the different studies, with the earliest survey conducted in 2004 and the most recent survey conducted in 2009. The surveys were conducted mostly by US mail (n = 12) or via the Internet (e-mail/Web sites; n = 9). Six studies used hand-delivered questionnaires (population = pharmacy students and patients), 2 used focus groups, 1 used interoffice mail, and 1 used a telephone survey. The objectives and outcomes of these surveys are summarized in Tables 1 and 2.

sec.title: Pharmacists
sec.p:
The majority of pharmacists surveyed stated an overall willingness, intention, or interest to provide MTM/direct patient care services. 12,14
–21,25,26,28 Most pharmacists claimed they have adequate clinical knowledge, experience, and access to information required for the provision of MTM services. 14,17,19 –21,26,27 However, across the surveys, the proportion of pharmacists who claimed to have provided these services varied widely from 16.2% to 86%. 12
–28 Pharmacists were also of the opinion that MTM services would be best provided by them and that the provision of MTM services would improve medication usage, therapeutic response/clinical outcome, quality of care/quality of life of patient, as well as satisfaction for both the patient and provider. 15,17,27 MTM services were mostly targeted at patients with diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, heart failure, HIV/AIDS, and other forms of chronic diseases. 13,16,25 –27 In addition, pharmacists also reportedly provided smoking cessation management, osteoporosis screening, immunization delivery, and anticoagulation services to their patients. 13,16,28

While the provision of MTM services is professionally rewarding for most pharmacists, surveys also identified barriers to the successful provision of these services. These barriers include lack of time, high workload, shortage of staff, reimbursement issues, lack of access to patients’ records, patients’ lack of interest, lack of collaborative practice agreement with physicians and the non-uniformity in program specification (ie, in design and delivery) by the different health plans. 13,14,16,18
–23,26 –28 Among the previously reported barriers, the most frequently occurring barrier across the majority of the pharmacist surveys are the issues surrounding reimbursement or compensation (eg, no payments, low and/or delayed payments, and profitability) for MTM services. Based on a study by Law et al, pharmacists would either want to be paid per minute (range $1-$10/min; mode $2) or per patient visit (range $10-$100/visit; mode $60). 20 Wang et al reported that pharmacists, on average, would be willing to accept $1.44/min or $86.4/hr for MTM services provided. 26 The need for compensation has also been shown to vary positively with the pharmacist’s years of practice as well as previous provision of MTM services. As regarding the profitability of the provision of MTM services, Schommer et al reported that almost an equal number of respondents who claimed they had a positive (35%) return on investment (ROI) reportedly had a negative (31%) ROI. 15 Pharmacists have also expressed interest in receiving additional training, especially in areas pertaining to billing and documentation. 14,20,21

Finally, pharmacists were more likely to provide MTM services if they (1) work in an independent pharmacy; (2) have lower workloads; (3) possess a PharmD degree; (4) work in a pharmacy that is located in a rural area but has a higher service orientation; and (5) are compensated for the services they render.

sec.title: Pharmacy Students
sec.p: Similar to pharmacists, the majority (73%-94%) of the pharmacy students surveyed was familiar with basic Medicare Part D drug benefit information and agreed to have the knowledge and skills to provide MTM services. These students were surveyed after been exposed to information on MTM services and/or Medicare drug benefits. 29 –31 Many of the pharmacy students had a positive attitude toward the provision of MTM services and were of the opinion that the provision of MTM services will improve medication outcomes, decrease health care costs as well as provide an opportunity to change patient behavior. 29,31 The majority (88%-93%) of the students felt that the provision of MTM services by pharmacists is crucial in providing patients with a higher level of care and in advancing the profession of pharmacy. 29,31 Pharmacy students were also reported to have a neutral view about the profitability of providing MTM services. In addition, despite a majority (60%-70%) agreed with the intention to provide MTM services, only few (37-38%) agreed to take the initiative to provide MTM if not currently offered by their employer. 29,31 However, this may not be representative of pharmacy students in general due to the use of convenient samples across the studies (ie, final year students and students who took an MTM class). 29 –31

sec.title: Physicians
sec.p: Two articles by Alkhateeb et al 33,34 reported on the same survey of physicians. Many of the physicians (over 50%) surveyed reported having little or no contact with a pharmacist regarding a patient’s medications or new prescription suggestions. 33,34 Similarly, in the survey by McGrath et al and Padiyara et al, only a few (17% and 36%, respectively) of the physicians had worked closely with pharmacists in an outpatient setting to optimize patient care. 32,35 However, many (60%-78%) of the physicians surveyed expressed a favorable attitude toward having a collaborative practice agreement with pharmacists in providing MTM services. 33 –35 Physicians were also of the opinion that the most important benefit of MTM lies in having a complete patient medication list. Compared to pharmacists, physicians felt they would be better at providing MTM services due to their clinical training. 35 Physicians were more comfortable having pharmacists adjust patients’ drug therapy (ie, drug dosage) and educate patients on general drug information and Medicare Part D prescription drug benefits. 32,34 Other services of interest to physicians include pharmacists provided disease education, information on medication-related devices, and smoking cessation services. 32 They were least comfortable with pharmacists providing immunization and asthma therapy services 34 and did not support the selection of patients’ drug therapy (ie, class of medications) by pharmacists. 32 In addition, physicians identified a number of potential issues associated with the provision of MTM services. These included the training/preparation of pharmacists, the payment system for services provided by the pharmacists, as well as payment for the time spent by physicians in coordinating care. 35

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Although patients agreed that MTM services should be provided by pharmacists, many of the patients surveyed (60%-93%) were not aware of its availability nor did they see the need for such services. 36,38,39,42 However, surveys conducted on patients who received pharmacist-provided MTM services revealed that the majority of these patients felt more knowledgeable about their medications and were satisfied with the program. 37,41,43 Furthermore, patients who recently visited a physician concerning a drug-related problem or regularly visit clinic pharmacies have been reported to be more favorable toward pharmacists’ provision of MTM services. 36 Patients’ willingness to pay for MTM services have also been shown to be low, with no significant relationship between patient’s willingness to pay for MTM services and complexity of the medication regimen. 38,40,42 In the study by Friedrich et al, patient’s willingness to pay was found to be associated with insurance status (lower for patients with public insurance compared to those with private insurance or no insurance) and presence of certain chronic conditions (lower for high cholesterol and high blood pressure compared with other diseases). 42 However, Law et al reported no association between insurance coverage and willingness to attend or pay for MTM services. 38 Other patient-reported barriers to receiving MTM services include inaccessibility to pharmacist MTM practice due to the location, parking, time of day/week; inability to fix appointments due to patients’ busy schedule; and fear of obtaining recommendations which may be contrary to their physician’s plan of care. 40 Furthermore, patients expressed the need for educational brochures and one-on-one consultation with their pharmacists. 39 They also recommended alternative ways through which MTM services can be described and marketed, including (1) developing a new name to describe MTM services or spelling out MTM in full and avoid the use of the acronym; (2) using marketing materials that patients can relate or identify with; (3) engaging employer-based “wellness champions” in marketing MTM services; and (4) having patients who have experienced the services tell others about it. 40

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Due to the benefits associated with the provision of MTM services (eg, improvement in health outcomes, increase in quality of health care, and reduction in the overall cost of care), the importance of developing strategies to address the barriers/challenges highlighted in the surveys cannot be overemphasized. 15,17,27 Pharmacists’ training needs have to be adequately addressed to improve their competencies as providers of MTM services. Courses on MTM services/patient care need to be fully integrated into the PharmD curriculum and residency programs as core courses in schools where they are currently offered as electives. A recent report by the APhA and the American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy (AACP) which summarized submissions received from 18 pharmacy schools and colleges on “successful practices to incorporate MTM into the curriculum” also emphasized the importance for early introduction and continuous reinforcement of the concept of MTM throughout the PharmD curriculum. 44 This report is a recommended resource for pharmacy schools.

Practicing pharmacists need to be able to access training materials or take classes on providing MTM services since the ability to deliver these services is crucial to the future of pharmacy. Issues surrounding compensation need to be adequately addressed such that pharmacists are paid based on the time and complexity of services provided. There is also the dire need to develop standardized interoperable billing and documentation systems that create a comprehensive and unified approach for integrating MTM services in electronic health records. 45 The roles of pharmacy technicians may have to be expanded to handle all nonclinically related activities (including paper work) to allow pharmacists to be better focused on patients’ needs. The importance of developing collaborative working relationships (CWRs) with other members of the health care team, especially physicians, needs to be emphasized beginning in pharmacy school. This will help pharmacists to effectively transition from being a product provider to eventually become involved in a patient-centered model of practice or team based-care with physicians and other health care personnel. This model of care has the potential to reduce the cost of care, improve the quality of care and efficiency of treatment of patients. Efforts should also be geared at educating physicians and other health care personnel on the value of MTM and the role of pharmacists as complementary (and not competitive) in improving patients’ health outcome and quality of care. Studies on pharmacist–physician CWR have shown the importance of a face-to-face communication with the physician, with the pharmacist being the relationship initiator. 46 –48 Other factors also considered to be important in establishing a pharmacist–physician CWR include trust, having high-quality pharmacist contributions, and role specification. 46,48 The potential benefits of a pharmacist–physician CWR on patient’s health outcome have also been documented. 49 –51

Furthermore, patients, health policy makers, and employers need to be adequately educated about the value of MTM services. An increased publicity on how pharmacists can help improve patients’ health outcomes (through education, proactive outreach/marketing, and/or employer incentive programs by waiving co-pays) will increase patients’ awareness and encourage them to participate in MTM services. 40,52 Finally, since few studies have been conducted to determine the ROI of providing MTM services, future MTM studies can also focus on this as positive ROIs would encourage more pharmacists to provide these services as well as provide payers with evidence of potential compensation for services.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: While the study sought to provide a summary of currently available published survey articles regarding MTM services in the United States, there is a possibility that some were not found by the literature search. It is also possible that other surveys regarding MTM may have been conducted but were not published (eg, used for plan decision making but not reported outside of the organization). In addition, the survey articles included in this study differ in research designs, different populations, and different research questions. Survey research has inherent limitations (eg, selection bias, responder’s bias, and/or low responder rates) which collectively limit the validity or generalizability of this summary and as such caution needs to be exercised in the use of the information presented.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid services (CMS) have recently mandated changes to MTM-related activities (eg, refine target criteria, target and enroll beneficiaries, perform ongoing monitoring of the beneficiaries medications). 53 However, there has been limited published studies investigating and documenting the results of these mandated changes and as such this summary can provide a reference for future research work that seeks to measure improvements in MTM services provided.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion, despite the identified barriers to the provision of MTM services, pharmacists reportedly found it professionally rewarding to provide these services. Pharmacists claimed to have adequate clinical knowledge, experience, and access to information required to provide MTM services. Pharmacy students were of the opinion that the provision of MTM services was important to the advancement of the pharmacy profession and in providing patients with a higher level of care. Physicians supported having pharmacists adjust patients’ drug therapy and educate patients on general drug information but not in selecting patients’ drug therapy. Finally, patients suggested that alternative ways need to be explored in describing and marketing MTM services for it to be appealing to them.
